titlestmt.titleproper: Collection of Confederate States of America Legal TenderMS187

repository.corpname: Digital Collections and Archives, Tufts University

did.unittitle: Collection of Confederate States of America Legal Tender

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is organized into one series.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p:
These materials were found in the Ryder Collection of Confederate Archives in 2011; the Ryder collection was cataloged as part of the WPA in 1939/1940 but in later decades the catalog (A Calendar of the Ryder Collection of the Confederate Archives at Tufts College 1940) was forgotten and library staff added other materials to the Ryder collection, usually items from the South, from the 18th and 19th century and around the time of the Civil War.
Because these materials were not part of the original Ryder collection, items were removed and a separate, 'artificial' collection was created.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains currency, loans, bonds, and a stamp by the Confederate States of America, and two Civil War currency notes from Virginia banks.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Some material in this collection may be protected by copyright and other rights. Please see "Reproductions and Use" on the Digital Collections and Archives website for more information about reproductions and permission to publish. No documentation is available regarding the intellectual property rights in this collection.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Collection of Confederate States of America Legal Tender, 1861 -- 1865. Tufts University. Digital Collections and Archives. Medford, MA.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Confederate States of America was a collection of eleven Southern states which formed a government when they seceded from the Union in 1860-1861. The government was led by Jefferson Davis, and lasted until the spring of 1865. Though the Confederacy carried on a major war, it ultimately was never recognized as a sovereign nation, and was disbanded after its defeat in the Civil War.

Prior to the outbreak of the war, the South felt their economy and traditions threatened by rising abolitionist sentiment in the North. With the election of Abraham Lincoln, seven states initially seceded from the Union: Alabama, Florida, Georgia, Louisiana, South Carolina, and Texas. After the first shots of the Civil War were fired at Fort Sumter, Arkansas, North Carolina, Tennessee, and Virginia additionally joined the Confederacy. Headed by President Jefferson Davis, the Confederacy created its own constitution, modeled after the U.S. Constitution. They also issued their own stamps and currency and adopted their own flag.

The principal issue of the Confederacy was raising and equipping an army to fight Union forces. Though bolstered by initial victories in 1861 and 1862, the army was defeated in battles at Gettysburg and Vicksburg, which shattered the illusion of the supremacy of their army. General Robert E. Lee and General Joseph E. Johnston were able to fend off the Northern armies in the North and West for a time, but ultimately were worn down by dwindling manpower and stronger Union armies. After the surrender of Robert E. Lee on April 9th, 1865, Confederate generals in the South subsequently surrendered or disbanded their armies. The Confederacy ceased to exist with the end of the Civil War, and each state was readmitted to the Union in the Reconstruction Era, after individually ratifying the 13th Amendment to the Constitution.

did.unittitle: Confederate bonds, loans, currency and stamp

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes Confederate States bonds, loans, currency and stamp and two civil war currency notes from Virginia banks.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged by classification system of published catalogs (all referenced).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 1 item, two fragments. Cotton Certificate for a $1,000 bond. Not numbered, no issue. Cotton Certificate for a $1000 bond. Dated Richmond lst November,1862 for 20 bales of cotton of 10,000 lbs. weight, to be delivered on demand by the Government at the port of New Orleans or Mobile on receiving thirty days notice. The demand to be made within the six months after the declaration of peace, in default of a demand within that period, the Certificate may be discharged by payment of $1000 with interest at 6% from the date of issue.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Illustrated with portrait of James A. Seddon of Va., CSA Secretary of War
Imprint Evans and; Cogswell, Columbia, S. C.

Left hand corner all 4 items have a faded squarish red stamp that bled through from the back page; stamp has rounded corners and in its center there is a red tree with an identical design left and right of tree (uncipherable)surrounded by 56a text: Department CSA Treasury.
Towards left hand corner all 4 items have engraved [handwritten] Sullivan; there must have been 2 plates as there are two versions of the engraved signature in capital letters.
Source: Ball, Douglas B., Comprehensive Catalog and History of Confederate Bonds (BNR Press, Port Clinton, Ohio 1998)

did.unittitle: Ten cents Confederate Treasury Note, Bank of the Empire State

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: GA-250 Bank of the Empire State, ca 1857-1860, Rome Georgia
Civil War Fractional Issues: Notes Payable in Confederate Treasury Notes (1863)
G[enuine]42 10 cents, April 1, 1863 [date fully engraved], similar to 20 cents, G44
Bottom right corner woman leaning on a barrel and a tied up bale? In her left hand holding a scepter with two snakes
will pay to bearer on demand ten cents in confederate treasury notes when presented in sums of five dollars. April 1st 1863.'
Source: Haxby, J. A., Standard Catalog of United States Obsolete Bank Notes, 1782-1866 (Krause Publications)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes transfer form on the back and stub on the left.
Imprint: Eng.d by Geo. Dunn and Co. Richmond, Va.
Unissued. Not signed. Not recorded. Not entered.
Stubs on left bottom corner have oval stamp in red, reading: GOOD Treasury. In the middle initials probably reading RHE
Source: Ball, Douglas B., Comprehensive Catalog and History of Confederate Bonds (BNR Press, Port Clinton, Ohio 1998)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: No Amount, field left empty to be filled by hand, ditto number and signatures.
4% certificate of indebtness, payable two years after peace. Passed under Act to reduce the Currency and to authorize a new issue of Notes and Bonds Feb 17 1864.
Source: Ball, Douglas B., Comprehensive Catalog and History of Confederate Bonds (BNR Press, Port Clinton, Ohio 1998)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Type 133 $500, Imprint: Evans and Cogswell, Columbia, S. C.
Printed on tan paper, different from the rest of this bond issue. The loan medallion is octagonal because the corners are clipped off.
Source: Ball, Douglas B., Comprehensive Catalog and History of Confederate Bonds (BNR Press, Port Clinton, Ohio 1998)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Engraved by George Dunn, printed by Hoyer and Ludwig
Washington equestrian monument [used in confederate coat of arms] west of the Virginia Capitol in Richmond)
One item has fragment of red stamp on right bottom corner; bottom corner partially torn off. Second item also has right bottom corner removed (possibly also had red stamp there.). Folds and tear
Source: Ball, Douglas B., Comprehensive Catalog and History of Confederate Bonds (BNR Press, Port Clinton, Ohio 1998)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Eight percent coupon bonds due July 1st 1878
Illustrated with Judah P. Benjamin portrait
Signed by Robert Tyler, (1816-1877), second register of the treasury, son of US President John Tyler by his first wife.
27 coupons still attached, numbered and signed by E. S. Read.
Printed by B. Duncan, Columbia, S.C.
Source: Ball, Douglas B., Comprehensive Catalog and History of Confederate Bonds (BNR Press, Port Clinton, Ohio 1998)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Illustrated with portrait of Vice President Alexander H. Stephens
Type 132 $100, Imprint: Evans and Cogswell, Columbia, S. C.
Date of Issue: March 2 1863. Number issued: 28,760 [higher than indicated numbers in reference source]
Lower right-hand corner: G(eorge) Wojciechovoski [sic], Lith.
Not signed by register of the treasury.
All 11 coupons ($4) attached; last coupon is missing all currency imprints. ($4) Coupons all signed by B. B. Jones
Source: Ball, Douglas B., Comprehensive Catalog and History of Confederate Bonds (BNR Press, Port Clinton, Ohio 1998)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Illustrated with Confederate officer overlooking the Rappahannock River west of Fredericksburg; bottom small illustration shows a steam boat against the backdrop of town (Richmond?)
Imprint Archer and Daly, Richmond, Va.
Unsigned. All 10 coupons (for 6 month interest) attached.
Source: Ball, Douglas B., Comprehensive Catalog and History of Confederate Bonds (BNR Press, Port Clinton, Ohio 1998)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Type 5. This is one of six note types actually signed by the register and treasurer. The government issues from Richmond were signed by the new register of the treasury, Robert Tyler, the son of U. S. President Tyler. Issued by Southern Bank Company, New Orleans.
Signed by treasurer: Edward C. Elmore

Illustrations: Hudson River Railroad scene at center. Justice left and Minerva right. Black with green overprint red-fiber paper. Bears interest One Cent Per Day. Some endorsed on back Received, Savannah, April 21 1863. Principal fo [sic] within Note, and Four hundred and Twenty Five Days Interest. And then dated and signed. All notes cancelled: cut cancel [slits of some design or shape, usually a cross with a bank hammer]; cut out cancel [some paper usually round or triangular shape removed; punch out cancel [small round holes].
Source: Criswell, Grover C. with Douglas B. Ball and Hugh Shull, Comprehensive Catalog of Confederate Paper Money (BNR Press: Ohio 1996)
Imprint: Southern Bank Note Company, New Orleans, although printed by the American Bank Note Company branch office in New Orleans.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Type 5. This is one of six note types actually signed by the register and treasurer. The government issues from Richmond were signed by the new register of the treasury, Robert Tyler, the son of U. S. President Tyler. Issued by Southern Bank Company, New Orleans.
Signed by treasurer: Edward C. Elmore

Illustrations: Hudson River Railroad scene at center. Justice left and Minerva right. Black with green overprint red-fiber paper. Bears interest One Cent Per Day. Some endorsed on back Received, Savannah, April 21 1863. Principal fo [sic] within Note, and Four hundred and Twenty Five Days Interest. And then dated and signed. All notes cancelled: cut cancel [slits of some design or shape, usually a cross with a bank hammer]; cut out cancel [some paper usually round or triangular shape removed; punch out cancel [small round holes].
Source: Criswell, Grover C. with Douglas B. Ball and Hugh Shull, Comprehensive Catalog of Confederate Paper Money (BNR Press: Ohio 1996)
Imprint: Southern Bank Note Company, New Orleans, although printed by the American Bank Note Company branch office in New Orleans.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Type 6. This is the last of the six note types actually signed by the register and treasurer. The government issues from Richmond were signed by the new register of the treasury, Robert Tyler, the son of U. S. President Tyler. This is the first Confederate note to bear a portrait of George Washington . Who as the father of the country, was claimed by both North and South. Issued by Southern Bank Company, New Orleans.
Signed by treasurer: Edward C. Elmore

Illustrations: Justice left, Agriculture and Industry seated on bale of cotton. Washington, right. Black with green overprint, red-fiber paper. Bears interest Half a Cent Per Day. Some endorsed on back Received, Savannah, April 21 1863. Principal fo [sic] within Note, and Four hundred and Twenty Five Days Interest. And then dated and signed. All notes cancelled: cut cancel [slits of some design or shape, usually a cross with a bank hammer]; cut out cancel [some paper usually round or triangular shape removed; punch out cancel [small round holes].
Imprint: Southern Bank Note Company, New Orleans, although printed by the American Bank Note Company branch office in New Orleans.
Source: Criswell, Grover C. with Douglas B. Ball and Hugh Shull, Comprehensive Catalog of Confederate Paper Money (BNR Press: Ohio 1996)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Illustrations: Large sailing vessel. Sailor at capstan, left. Blank back.
Engraver: Hoyer and Ludwig, Richmond VA
Source: Criswell, Grover C. with Douglas B. Ball and Hugh Shull, Comprehensive Catalog of Confederate Paper Money (BNR Press: Ohio 1996)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

Engraver: B. Duncan, Columbia, S. C.
Source: Criswell, Grover C. with Douglas B. Ball and Hugh Shull, Comprehensive Catalog of Confederate Paper Money (BNR Press: Ohio 1996)

Signed for treasurer: facsimile signature E. C. Elmore

Engraver: Archer and Daly, Richmond, Va.
Source: Criswell, Grover C. with Douglas B. Ball and Hugh Shull, Comprehensive Catalog of Confederate Paper Money (BNR Press: Ohio 1996)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Signed for register: Pelot, Mrs. A. P.
Illustrations: State capitol of Richmond, Va, center; C. G. Memminger, right. Reddish network overprint background. Ornate blue back with Five in large letters.
Engraver: Keating and Ball, Columbia, S. C.
Source: Criswell, Grover C. with Douglas B. Ball and Hugh Shull, Comprehensive Catalog of Confederate Paper Money (BNR Press: Ohio 1996)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Signed for register: Taylor, Mrs. Miriam
Signed for treasurer: Korff, Miss Kate
Illustrations: State capitol of Richmond, Va, center; C. G. Memminger, right. Reddish network overprint background. Ornate blue back with Five in large letters.
Engraver: Keating and Ball, Columbia, S. C.
Source: Criswell, Grover C. with Douglas B. Ball and Hugh Shull, Comprehensive Catalog of Confederate Paper Money (BNR Press: Ohio 1996)

did.unittitle: Five dollar bill, Trans-Alleghany Bank of Virginia, Jeffersonville

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Trans-Alleghany Bank of Virginia, Jeffersonville: 1853-ca.1855, but bank notes were dated and used up to the 1860s.
Signed by state treasurer: Thomas Mons[sp?]
Signed by cashier and president of bank
Engraver: Danforth, Wright and Co, New York and Philad.
Source: Haxby, J. A., Standard Catalog of United States Obsolete Bank Notes, 1782-1866 (Krause Publications: DVD 2009)

did.unittitle: One dollar bill, Virginia Treasury Note, Richmond

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Signed for treasurer: J. S. Calvert
Illustration: Maiden with pail seated on log at the center. Large red ONE protector below. Oval portrait of Governor Letcher at the lower left.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This is either the first or second issue of the first stamp issued by the Confederate States since the faded stamps make it impossible to determine if stamps are blueish or greenish and the color indicates the issue. The stamp is the first stamp issued on American soil to display the likeness of a living president and is also the first stamp printed by stone lithography.
Designer and Engraver: Charles Ludwig. Printing Method: Stone Lithography. Lithographer: Hoyer and Ludwig, Richmond, Virginia.
